tweet: Well that was spooky. Old neighbor with dementia came to my door and asked me what year it was. Then something about her son being here. Then the son found her to take her home. Feel bad for them.

My wife & her brother have put dad into a memory care home. Dementia.

It’s sad, & both bemoan how they can’t have a rational visit with someone so irrational.

It’s the same with MTG.

@lynne_drummond @oldagepsych Glad you were there to stick up for Grandma- I worry how many folk don’t have a sensible/pugnacious advocate. I had to stand up for my mum (severe dementia) who broke her hip but they were tentative with pain relief in case she became addicted ....

tweet: @MarisolVaz8 I am so sorry.  With Alz it’s inevitable, but it’s hard not to take it personally.   Alz is worse than cancer, as it takes away who the patient is way before they actually die, physically.  Please be kind to both yourself and your dad.  It’s disease making him forget—no fault.

@CheenieWrites @theoriesofcare Same. I grieve the 8 yr loss of my mother, and yes- she’s still alive-but no-contact. My Dad has Alzheimer’s, but my grief is for being barred from seeing him&showing him love. Messy&complicated grief like this is deemed “private” by society so support isn’t there, either.

tweet: “I never been lonely or bored in my life, never, and I guess that comes from not having a mother,” he says. His mom was put in a psychiatric hospital with dementia praecox when he was 7. “I never had a mother, and I’ve been trying to find one since then” thr.cm/zKeoHYd

I cannot visit my mother while she is awake. Her dementia changed her. She is violent and verbally abusive. I wait until she’s in a deep sleep to hold her hand. She still wears her wedding ring. I hope her soul recognizes the soul of her daughter. I’d like to think that it does.

tweet: @JesusFChristo My great grandma and my grandma both died from alzheimers. It was hard. So hard... I'm so sorry you're going thru this.

I took care of dad when he had Alzheimer’s, and was the one staying home so that he was safe, and this is giving me some feelings.

It’s always a complicated and individual situation.

Much love and sympathy to anyone else dealing with similar situations.

@yashar My Cajun grandparents refused to teach their kids English. My grandfather had Alzheimer's and only remembered his French.

tweet:
So #Alzheimers & #dementia sucks. It's been a slow goodbye w/ both my Grandparents (the only "parental" figures I ever really had). Adding to that, I've learned that much of Grandmother's family died from either.

My grandma, for example, has frontotemporal dementia.

Finally home again, that was one exhausting weekend at my Dad's. Didn't get much sleep. Dementia sucks!
But he did well today... of course on race day my Dad is up to speed again... literally. So we had fun... I just need to catch up on sleep! #dementiasucks #lovemydad

@Jennife10651535 @YourMrBumbles @BBCPM I have a soft spot for Shostakovich. Played 2nd flute and piccolo in his fifth. I don't listen to that in the same way my son does. 
I think dementia is a varied thing, affects people so differently. In some it changes the personality, in others it is in perception areas. Or both
